awd_titl_txt: Tuning Interfacial Biomolecule Interactions with Massively Parallel Nanopore Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
DNA stores biological information with a very high density. New tools of genomics and genetic engineering that have emerged over the past 20 years, providing the transformative capabilities to both "read" DNA, and to "write" DNA. New biosensors that diagnose diseases and predict responses to treatments can be based on "reading" DNA, and development of new pest-resistant crops, for example, can be based on "writing" DNA. While DNA is protected when inside living cells, it is relatively unstable when exposed to environments outside of cells. This work will advance our understanding of how DNA interacts with a new class of materials with DNA-sized, nanoscale pores. The chemistry of these pores can be tuned to optimize interactions with DNA, for storage, stability, and for reporting specific chemical binding events. In future work, these materials could be used to develop new biosensors and advanced nanomaterials that could store DNA or transduce mechanical and chemical signals through controlled DNA binding. 

We will study the interactions of short DNA segments with the surfaces and pores of crosslinked protein crystals, by atomic force microscopy and adsorption isotherm measurements. Diffusion of DNA within nanopores will be characterized by fluorescence microscopy methods. Finally, we will assess the ability of protein crystals to: stabilize guest DNA, couple DNA-pore interactions to ligand binding on the protein crystal surface, and report DNA hybridization through fluorescence.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This work investigated newly discovered interactions of DNA and other large molecules with engineered protein-based materials. The protein-based materials have a highly-ordered crystalline structure composed of nanoscale pores. The nanoscale pores have the newly discovered ability to bind DNA and other large molecules on their interior. The strength of binding the DNA to the interior of the protein crystal pores can be measured using high-resolution atomic force microscopy. This binding also depends upon the length of the DNA. Longer DNA molecules bind to the interior of the protein crystal pores more strongly than shorter DNA. We discovered that this binding extends to some other types of molecules, as well, and is dependent upon both the chemistry and the length of the molecules.

We further used the binding of molecules inside the nanopores to present important molecular signals to attached mammalian cells. These signals control the cell binding to the surface through transduction of adhesion forces. By tuning the forces of adhesion between cells and nanostructured materials, we can design materials surfaces that control cell behavior through controlled adhesion forces.  Controlling cell behavior through nanomaterials may provide a method to regulate cells involved in inflammation, cancer cell migration, bone healing, nerve regeneration, and blood vessel stiffening, through tuning nanomaterials interaction.


Last Modified: 02/27/2022
Modified by: Matthew J Kipper
